org.jay3d.engine.core.math

Class Attenuation

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jay3d.engine.core.math.Vector3f
      • org.jay3d.engine.core.math.Attenuation

  • public class Attenuation
extends Vector3f
    The attenuation value is the gradual loss of intensity through the 3D space. Whilst travelling from it's original source, it usually diminishes in intensity, which is why it is often called, "light attenuation".

    The real-attenuation tends to be 100% quadratic, however this easily easily interpreted in virtual environments such as the Rendering Engine due to the number of calculations required. By blending the three values that constitutes the lights attenuation you are able to set the proportions of each type as you feel like.

    Therefore an attenuation ratio of 3:6:1 will yield the same result as 6:12:2 or 30:60:10.

    The class itself is simply a convenience class that changes Vector3f into attenuation, to replace:

    Vector3f(float x, float y, float z) which are the axis with

    Attenuation(float constant, float linear, float exponent)

    Constant the the amount of strength that the light scatters

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Attenuation(float constant, float linear, float exponent)
      Constructs and initialises the attenuation for the given light object.

      Not to be confused with Linear, this means that the further the light travels from it source, the 'more' it will dimishes.
      float getLinear()

    • Constructor Detail

      • Attenuation

        public Attenuation(float constant,
                   float linear,
                   float exponent)
        Constructs and initialises the attenuation for the given light object.
        Parameters:
        constant - The amount of strength that that the light scatters
        linear - The rate that the light dimishes as it travels from it's source
        exponent - Not to be confused with Linear, this means that the further the light travels from it source, the 'more' it will dimishes. This creates a sharp drop in light to compensate for fast decline

        public float getLinear()
        The rate that the light dimishes as it travels from it's source
        Returns:
        The Attenuation's linear value

      • getExponent

        public float getExponent()
        Not to be confused with Linear, this means that the further the light travels from it source, the 'more' it will dimishes. This creates a sharp drop in light to compensate for fast decline
        Returns:
        The Attenuation's exponential value
